conclusion: A beam of light enters the prism ABCD perpendicularly from point O along AD. The prism is a right triangular prism with AB = BC = 8 cm and OA = 2 cm. The angle ∠OAB = 60°. The refractive index of the prism, n = √2.
Since the beam enters perpendicularly along AD, the angle of incidence at point A is 0°.
The right triangle AOB helps determine the geometry inside the prism.
Point A is at the origin. Point O is 2 cm along the x-axis. Point B is 8 cm along the y-axis (since AB = 8 cm and ∠OAB = 60°).
The critical angle for total internal reflection is θc = arcsin(1/n). With n = √2, θc = arcsin(1/√2) = 45°.
The light ray enters perpendicularly at A and continues to point E on side AB. At point E, the light ray hits the side AB at an angle of incidence i.
Use Snell's Law to determine the angle of refraction r: n sin(i) = sin(r). Since the ray is perpendicular to AD and hits AB at 60°, i = 60°.
Calculate r: sin(60°) = sin(r), sin(r) = √3/2, r = arcsin(√3/2) = 60°.
The light ray exits the prism at point F along BC. The direction of the light ray when it first exits the prism is along the line extending from E to F.
The light ray first exits the prism at point F along BC, and the direction is determined by the path through the prism.
